author: axic3354
content:
The other thing I was wondering about the wrapping (just didn't had enough time on the call) what is more important:
1) to require only rlp decoding or only rlp encoding? 
2) to able to check if the signature is not flipped?
3) to be able to validate more properties of the transaction?

To that end, what if the wrapped format is completely SSZ and contains each field unwrapped. Then the client needs to RLP encode the non-signature fields in order to check the signature.  In this case transaction validity could be checked without rlp decoding, but with rlp encoding.

Don't take these as change proposal, rather just questions we could briefly discuss. Probably the current approach regarding wrapping is the best, even in my opinion.

author: axic3354
content:
Let's say it is fully unwrapped:
`0x01 || yParity || r || s || chainid || nonce || gasPrice || gasLimit || to || value || data`

e.g.

```
Tx:
  type: uint8
  yparity: boolean
  r: bytes32
  s: bytes32
  chainid: uint64
  nonce: uint64
  gasPrice: uint256
  gasLimit: uint64
  to: bytes20
  value: uint256
  data: bytes
```

(Also note chainid/nonce/gasLimit limitations are subject to other EIPs proposing it. Per YP they are undefined/256-bit.)

One "problem" arises here is that now there is no way to quickly validate whether this transaction is truncated (because there is no length field for `data` encoded), wheres RLP would include the length.
